swift/cli/info.py.message:
These stats are a little funny -- but I'm not sure how to make them more useful yet. When everybody's active, it's definitely useful:

Shard Ranges (1545):
  States:
       active: 1545
  Max objects: 920299
  Min objects: 24
  Avg objects: 316840.7197411003

I.e. everybody's under a million rows, there's at least one shard that's probably getting close to splitting, and there's at least one shard that ought to shrink.

For more complicated states, it's less useful:

Shard Ranges (62):
  States:
      created: 2
      cleaved: 4
       active: 54
     sharding: 2
  Max objects: 1107546
  Min objects: 0
  Avg objects: 481093.79032258067

So we've got a shard up at 1.1M objects -- but that's most likely one of the two that's already in the process of sharding itself. We've also got some at 0, but that's likely one of the created DBs -- it just hasn't reported stats yet (assuming it's even received some redirects).

We could bucket stats by status... but I'm not sure that all statuses will be interested in the same stats. I need to think some more...

manifests/function/hostgenerator-m3/READ.message:
Is there a specific reason to put this site-level common networking catalogue under the 'type' dir? Why not under site/test-site/shared?
I guess I'm asking for the exact difference between a site and a type, are they overlapping or disjoint?

Sites are like instantiations of a type -- there are two pieces to splitting them up like this is to cut down on different sites that are essentially the same, aside from things like IP addresses.  Cuts down on duplication across site definitions.

From a kustomize perspective, sites would be pulling the type-level catalogues in (along with other k8s widgets).
Ah! I see, that makes it totally clear.

There's an "/ephemeral/boostrap/hostgenerator/host-generation.yaml" and "/ephermeral/controlplane/hostgenerator/host-generation.yaml". Maybe this reference needs to be fixed? Like, do we mean both of these catalogues, or any one?
I think we mean more like an "/ephemeral/*/hostgenerator/host-generation.yaml"
Whoops, you're right -- either one of them will serve as an example, but apparently I hedged my bets by picking neither of them; will fix.

So, a full update cycle would look like
1- Update this YAML file with the desired changes you need to layer.
2- Kubectl apply this
3- Let the controller reconcile and update the resource

I feel like I'm missing something here

By "layered", I mean "kustomized".  Since the site will be pulling in things via kustomize from the "parent" type anyway, kustomize gives the hook to make changes to those documents.

To be clear, this isn't saying "deploy vanilla documents then update them", it's more like "generate vanilla documents via the kustomize plugin and then kustomize them at site level prior to deployment".
"prior to deployment", that's what I was missing. Got it.

manifests/site/test-site/ephemeral/boots.message:
It related to bare metal as MAC addresses
We should place them together in host.yaml.

We have BMC (real baremetal) properties:
1. MAC's
2. Boot MAC
2. URL
3. Credentionals

How can it depend on а phase?

BMH ( BMC and some properties kind of labels, credentialsName: external_provisioned )

I think, this properties depend upon the phase.

Just to be clear, I didn't come up with that - it's the existing value form the base revision :)  the goal of this PS was to take the existing airshipctl test-site BMH definitions and recreate them via the host generator.  If we're making things too complex by having multiples, then it's a win that the generator can carry the (unneeded) burden.

One thing that comes to mind is, since many BMCs out there, can support multiple OOB protocols, for instance an iDRAC card can support IPMI, Redfish and WSMAN (iDRAC), there is a possibility, for whatever reason, to have different BMC addresses in different phases of deployment, for whatever reason. 
I'm not sure on the use case/scenario though, but just think it's possible this way, which  makes the issue that Matt is trying to solve as an edge case, rather than a typical use case.

The issue here being solved for here is that for a single host (node02), two different BMC addresses were being used in different phases.  I.e. there was a "normal" one defined in hosts.yaml, and then this ephemeral one which is was different.

We should probably refactor and/or document this setup as follow-on work; I wanted to change the BMH content as little as possible as part of this PS (it's big enough already).

Oh, I wasn't aware of that. Well, in that case, yes, it really is an added bonus if we can handle such complications. Probably worth mentioning somewhere that this approach has the ability to circumvent such issues, would be helpful for others in the future. I'll say README is the place to go?

manifests/site/test-site/shared/catalogu.message: I'm guessing this is to support multiple host providers? with M3 referring to the host being provided by CAPM3?
Makes sense, since various providers might have their own way (parameter set) of defining their 'host', so labeling like this would be helpful. I think it's good.
Yep, that was the idea, to leave room for that.  Not sure if it's really all that valuable or not.
Is this the MAC address for the boot interface? or the iDRAC interface?

It's for the PXE interface, see the (duplicate) definition below.  I'll say "I'm just the middleman" for this one -- the BMH/networking that this PS is replacing was already set up that way; there may be a cleaner way to represent that, I'm not sure.

I guess then this bring up the question of why are we doing this duplication? Is there value in having a 'readily available' node01.macAddress field for some reason?
Assuming there is, might be better to rename this to 'bootMACAddress' or something similar, just for some clarity, to facilitate its usage.

It is unclear why here was used "air-target-1" name similar to node01.
And different IPs.
Sounds good. Should be able to resolve confusions first. What patch overrides this? Can you point me to it? I'd like to study that.

I could have sworn I got that from pre-existing work (and just moved it around), but can't find that now.  I'll change this to "air-target-2" since that's a more sane/consistent value -- even though it gets overridden by a patch (which is valuable to demonstrate).

The Redfish specification does require the resource to be unique within an implementation, so technically it will be valid to have "air-target-1" in both instances of redfish in both nodes.
However, I do agree that although legal, this can be confusing, and we need to either clarify the purpose of it, or rename it to maybe, 'air-target-2' here.
Agree, it's not clear to me either.

pkg/document/plugin/templater/v1alpha1/t.message: Any specific reasons we're swallowing errors here?

Excellent reviewing, ty - this one is because all I wanted to do was replicate the toYaml function from Helm, which is where this snippet came from. Helm has the error handling like so, and I just assumed they had some good reason for it.    I'd certainly be open to doing something smarter if it's appropriate.

I'll add a note here saying from whence this function came.

Ah, I see. So, I believe the function you're talking about is this one https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/bb47286f09331271e88e6047c51fd6e0ea936506/pkg/engine/funcs.go#L83
Reading the comment above the function definition says "this function is to be called from a template". Which I guess clarifies this. 

Since the function will always be called from a template, for it to silently swallow errors might be desirable, to ensure stability of template definitions. Last thing you want is somebody writing templates and having to face an error code that might be too complicated for them to digest.

A way to document this fact somewhere saying "hey, if the toYAML silently fails and doesn't perform substitution as expected, this could be the reason" might be helpful for people crafting templates for their environments. A note or something in the documentation. It's good that you added the comment in the code, for anybody wishing to understand it that way.
This is a good way to attribute this function.

Apart from the commit message, I was talking about the answer to norman. I'll copy it here:

This patch provides solution for all those scenarios:

- Not DVR, existing flows in both bridges. The initialization won't affect the current traffic.
- DVR, existing flows in both bridges. The drop flow in phy-br, in table 0 with prio 2 won't overwrite the existing DVR flow (prio 3), to submit the traffic to table 1
- Not DVR, flows cleaned. The drop flows will prevent the traffic between both bridge types (integration and physical bridges)
- DVR, flows cleaned. The OVSDVRNeutronAgent.setup_dvr_flows_on_phys_br will install the default flows for DVR in the physical bridge. Until the OVS does not start configuring the VLANs, the flows in the physical bridge will block any traffic [1]

Please, read the commit message and the answer to norman. There you can find the explanation.

If you need further information, don't hesitate to ping me here or in IRC (#openstack-neutron, @ralonsoh)

BTW, can you try this patch in your env? Thanks!

This is the key point of this patch. We can install this flow with DVR because the priority (2) is lower than the DVR flow priority (3) installed in the local switch table, to send the traffic to table 1.

This is the only purpose of us overriding the function: to rewrite self.raw_requestline ahead of CPython's processing so we can work around https://bugs.python.org/issue33973.

Eventlet's get_environ() populates RAW_PATH_INFO based on the protocol's path: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/v0.25.1/eventlet/wsgi.py#L667

That path, in turn is set in CPython's parse_request(), based on the value of raw_requestline: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v3.8.3/Lib/http/server.py#L333

Hi LIU Yulong,

I don't see the need to increase the priority of the goto. The drop flow should only exist in table 0 when DVR is not enabled. With DVR the drop flow is in table 2 instead.
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/73557abefcba1c6ce0cef709d1082674c0217485/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_dvr_neutron_agent.py#L267-L270

Example with DVR enabled:

# ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-physnet1 --no-stats --names | cut -d',' -f2-
 priority=2,in_port="phy-br-physnet1" actions=resubmit(,1)
 priority=0 actions=NORMAL

 table=2, priority=4,in_port="phy-br-physnet1",dl_vlan=6 actions=mod_vlan_vid:100,NORMAL
 table=2, priority=2,in_port="phy-br-physnet1" actions=drop

 table=3, priority=1 actions=NORMAL

DVR disabled:

 priority=2,in_port="phy-br-physnet1" actions=drop
 priority=0 actions=NORMAL

This is, in practice, like reverting 90212b12.

As commented in the previous patch (the revert), why don't you explore the option of tagging the traffic coming into the int-br from the phys-brs?

In case the OVS has been restarted (no flows remain from previous executions), the traffic from the physical bridges can be tagged in the local switching table (0), for example writing a register.

Then, in the physical bridges, you can add rules to drop this tagged traffic. That will prevent what you describe in the bug.

> The traffic will be blocked, in practice is a revert

I tested this patch with and without dvr, and there is no traffic interuption on agent restart. 
I know the test is good because at 10 pings/sec and commit "Do not block connection between br-int and br-phys on startup" reverted, I always see drops.
This patch does not cause a regression of bug 1869808.

> The traffic will be blocked, in practice is a revert

Rodolfo, please explain to me how exactly this flow on br-int could possibility cause a traffic interruption on agent restart.

The traffic will be blocked, in practice is a revert

Right, the registers are not passed when using normal action.

Just one last option: did you try to configure STP in all bridges? You can do this manually and test it. Is it possible for you?

> (This is just my preference) the DVR traffic should be handled only
 > in DVRAgent; this condition "enable_distributed_routing" should not

fair enough. But my patch did not add that condition. It was already in master.

This could work, actually.

(This is just my preference) the DVR traffic should be handled only in DVRAgent; this condition "enable_distributed_routing" should not be here.

Anyway, you are right, this patch does not overwrite the phy br rule. I'll remove the -1, but I prefer my solution.

This drop flow can cause traffic interruption with DVR in a live environment (please, remember this matrix of DVR/non-DVR - live traffic/flows removed).

As said, with DVR and live traffic, this drop flow will overwrite [1]. This rule takes the traffic coming into the physical bridge and submit it to DVR_PROCESS_PHYSICAL (table 1). Other flows will process the traffic from this point.

If, as commented in [2], the RPC channel is down or unresponsive, between the drop flow (applied during the physical bridge initialization) and [1] (applied during the DVR class initialization), there will be a period of time where the traffic coming into the phys bridge will be dropped.

Instead of this, for the case of DVR with live traffic, instead of setting prio 2 in [1], Liu and I recommended to set prio 3. That will work for all cases [3].

I agree. Commit message says attachments will always be there, but what about the case when upgrading from a release before the new attachment changes. I think in that case, there may be a chance this is not present. So just to be safe, I would rather see a get() call here.

-1: I think we should do this in the _get_attachment method by passing the request variable, or just passing ctx.is_admin

Nit: i'd suggest making the is_admin the second parameter with a default value of False, and that way you won't break any current calls to _get_attachments() that only pass the volume (our test coverage isn't so great that you can be 100% sure that you caught them all).

We never pass True or False directly here rather context.is_admin
It's safe but not a candidate to have a default value.
Suppose if someone uses this method and forgets to pass the is_admin part, then an admin user will never be able to see the host info in that call.
This way it is mandatory to pass the is_admin when calling this method.
I understand with respect to the security fix but i don't think this variable can have a default value as it is based on the user context and is dynamic.

I have seen bugs being introduced in both cases, when we add a default value and when we don't, and in the second case it's always because missing or bad unit tests.

In this case I agree with Rajat. It is OK to add the new parameter and not set a default value because:

- It is a protected variable
- We are only calling the method in one place in our whole code (L95)
- It is a necessary parameter to return the right value (having a default could create a bug when we add new code if we forget to pass the parameter).

That's fine, but note that is_admin=False is the safe option here (i.e., the sensitive info will *not* be exposed).  So the only time you'd see the sensitive info is when the caller has explicitly passed is_admin=True.

I understand your point for a generalized scenario but in this case
1) this is a private method so it is highly unlikely that it is used outside of cinder
2) I did a codesearch[1] and the only usage i see is in cinder on L#95 (atleast in openstack) so i think in this case it is safe to modify the method signature.

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=_get_attachments&i=nope&files=&repos=

We're talking at cross purposes here.  Let me try to explain.

You are refactoring an existing function to fix a bug.  You don't want to a cause a regression somewhere else as a side effect of your fix.  Your change makes this function go from 1 required parameter to 2.  So it's possible that if you don't catch all instances of calls to this function and change them, you'll get a TypeError at some point when only 1 parameter is passed, and whatever API call is in process will blow up.  That will be worse than an admin making a call and not seeing the host name.

So giving the parameter a default value is a way to preserve the existing method signature in a safe way.  My suggestion isn't about this particular function, it's a more general point about maintaining a large software project that has less than perfect unit test coverage (i.e., every large software project).

When you write a new function, you can decide what parameters are mandatory.  When you are working with existing code (this function has been around since 2012), you need to be a bit more flexible, or you may wind up introducing another problem.

I don't think assigning a default value is the right thing here. that assumes the _get_attachments call is always from a non-admin.
We should handle every call to this method with proper context and currently i only see one.
I will update this as a second parameter in a new PS.

so today in the api while we block attach we do not block detach. the detach will complete form the api successfully but will not release the claim on the vf.

the claim will be fixed if the vm is live migrated or deleted but not for other move operation like cold migrate or shelve.
i did not check evalucate but i suspect it would not be cleaned in that case either.
Thanks. I can mention this issue in the spec. However I suggest to handle the blocking of detach as bugfix because we want to backport the blockade.

so do we also want to track the cnages for sriov pf detach in this sepc and or blocking the detach optional via config at the api.

i was going to fix the pf detach as a bugfix becuase i wanted to backport that so that numa live migration could be fixed altthough there is a differen issue once detach is fixed that likely would need to be adress before pf live migratoin actully works. specificly the mac adress need to be updated which is why vms with pf passthohg cant be cold or live migrated currently. again i was going to track fixing that as a seperate bug since at least the cold migratoin case was expected to work even thohg it was never actully implemeted correctly.
I'm fine handling the PF detach case as a separate bugfix due to the NUMA case. You can still add that patch top of mine if you wish.
What if the claim is unsuccessful ? I guess the instance action will be errored but the instance status will be back to ACTIVE ?
Yes. The instance state never changes during the interface attach action.
we would still have races like for other instance actions in case we have a problem in between the Neutron call and the virt driver, but meh, it's already the same issue for all instance actions.
Yeah, this is no different from how the code behaves today.
cool with me if you also provide the bugfix in the commit msg.

specs/ussuri-template.rst.message: Does we need to require this in nova SPEC? AFAIK, there are few core concern the OSC, that review is slowly, that may can prevent the feature's progress.

well we could consider removing the nova clinet too.

par to the reason the gaps exist was we could not get the updates landed in osc in the past.

i know that there is an intent to adress that.

if we want to encourage updating the openstack client i would instead think we might want to consider freezing the nova clinit for new feature or require that all new feature to nova clinet must also have a patch to osc.

if we dont do that then the gap will never be closed.
at the end of the day we want osc to be the way that nova is consumed on the command line and freezing nova clinet is one way to help with that.
It is a pity that mriedem will not be deeply involved in OpenStack anymore.

It's a bit of a chicken and egg thing - we don't make it mandatory because of the gaps, and we don't close the gaps because it's not mandatory. At some point we have to start doing one or both of those. mriedem started tracking the gaps and closing them, I'd like to continue that during V. If we make it mandatory, it'll mean we won't have new gaps continually opening.

> if we want to encourage updating the openstack client i would
 > instead think we might want to consider freezing the nova clinit
 > for new feature or require that all new feature to nova clinet must
 > also have a patch to osc.

Note that we can't freeze novaclient (at least not the python binding) because the way OSC works is by calling the novaclient python binding. Until someone overhauls the way OSC works with nova (e.g. to use the openstacksdk and not novaclient), that will be the case.

Also, as you've already said, I don't think it would be right to freeze novaclient when OSC can't do the same things as novaclient. IMHO the best way forward is to at least have new changes add to both clients.

I don't think we can freeze novaclient and only roll forward with openstackclient only due to the existing gap. But I think we should make openstackclient changes mandatory. The we will see the failure mode of such requirement (e.g. slowness of osc review) and then we work on fixing that failure mode.

specs/victoria-template.rst.message: ok but since we already advice against using the nova client in any docs where the openstack client can be used im not sure it makes sese to enhance the nova clinet for new features. using the openstack sdk instead of nova client to implement new featues is exactly what i had in mind to enable us to freeze the nova client for new feature and say all new feature must be added to the openstack client. the intent being to force people to use osc so we can eventural remove nova clinet when the parity gaps are closed.

I don't want to enter this specific discussion (requiring support of both OSC and novaclient in V) *now* since it's a large effort that needs more than just gerrit reviews.

FWIW, the above phrase looks good to me for just saying that people should think about other clients, not only novaclient.

Good enough for me.

We cannot force user to use openstack client. Due to the gap, we can only suggest. This is what we do in our documentation today. 

Is it possible to add the next nova related change on openstack client via the openstacksdk instead of via python-novaclient? Or such change needs a sizable per-requisite patch first in the nova part of the openstack client?

im not saying we should force them to use only openstack client. i am say we should force them to use openstack cleint to get new features.

yes we can add new openstack client feature for nova using the sdk, we do not need to continute to extend python-novaclient to add new fature to osc. we just extend nova client first today because its easier to do most of the work once there and then reuse it on osc.

if the sdk does not supprot a given api then supporit will have to be added for that but that should be a similar amount of work to adding it to nova client.

anyway weather we do it this cycle or two or three cycle from now i think we should be planning for the removal of nova client and planning to feature freeze it at some point.

i dont think its unreasonable to require users to use both client.  i only use nova clinet very very rearly for feature that are not in osc. i suspect the same is true for many people so i dont think the feature gaps are extreme enough that many people will notice or care.

Can we try to require support for both clients in V cycle? By doing that we will gather confidence about merging the openstackclient patches for each V feature in this cycle. Then based on that knowledge we can propose freezing nova CLI in the next cycle.

Is it write_image or data param that should really drive  when this function returns image_chunks?

As far as I understand we want to return the image_chunks iterator to allow the caller to process the image data. We can only do that if we do not consumed the iterator. We consume the iterator:
* if we do verification or
* if we write image out to data file obj or to dst_path

There is a hidden bug here which was possibly exists in the original code too. 
If there is no data or dst_path is provided then no data will be written out and the image_chunk is returned. But if there is verifier returned by  _get_verifier() then this function consumes the image_chunk iterator for verification and then returns a consumed iterator. So the caller cannot do the data copying later.

As this is unrelated to your current patch series lets have this fixed in a totally separate patch.

specs/victoria/approved/glance/copy-unow.message:
I think it would be worth adding something here about ownership of the copy just to be completely clear (i.e., the original image owner still owns the copy, not the user who initiated the copy operation.)

Also, there was some talk in #openstack-glance about restricting this to images with public visibility?  Or did we decide not to do that?

About ownership: I think it's true that we understand it, but I can see people using the "copy-image" feature and wondering what happened to "their" copy.

About image visibility: I think what you have here is fine, it's clear that it's controlled by a policy rule.  I just wanted to make sure we weren't missing anything.

I guess I thought it's clear that a copy-image doesn't affect the original image in any way other than adding a new location at the end. I can surely say something like that here if you think it's important, but since there's no new object created (i.e. a new image record) I would have thought it was well-understood.

We did say "public" but the code I've got just makes it a policy knob, which you can write as "allow copying public images" or something more complex. Given how much you can do with policy rules (up to calling out to an external decider service via http) I didn't think it was important to define a box around what you can do, since it's just "whatever you can do with policy". Maybe I just need to be clear(er) here that this is controlled by a policy rule?

> About ownership: I think it's true that we understand it, but I can
 > see people using the "copy-image" feature and wondering what
 > happened to "their" copy.

Okay, seems like that's a matter for the documentation of the feature more so than the spec. However, I'll put something here and also add a work item below to update the copy-image doc to explain what it means if you're granted this permission on an image you don't own. Sound okay?

The problem is that patch cannot be backported, and we need something that can work on stable/train. My intention is for this patch to serve that purpose. The full solution involves 3 steps.

2. My puppet-cinder patch [1] for V onward (merged, but cannot be backported)
3. Update THT to consolidate the barbican client settings (relies on [1])

Step 3 will eliminate the cinder::config::cinder_config by switching to the new puppet-cinder settings.
